poem:
**Echoes of the Past**

Brick Lane, White Abbey Road,  
where echoes crackle and flare—  
the shadows of history nosing  
through cobblestones. Here,  
memory stitches the air,    
the stitching unraveling once more,  
carrying whispers of flames,  
a landscape charred by fear.  
Still, we walk, weaving between  
the quivers of what once was,  
hopeful threads entwined with caution.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It has cycled back around’: Brick Lane and Bradford fear a repeat of infamous far-right clashes The shoppers and shopkeepers of White Abbey Road in Bradford well remember a time almost 25 years ago when the street was engulfed in flames after a protest march against the National Front turned violent. On east London’s Brick Lane, the British-Bangladeshi population remember the invisible lines they could not cross without being set upon by the far right.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
